_prev_prog_3.Description: Delta Liquid Energy`s Prevention Program includes a Management System, a Hazard Analysis, Operating Procedures, an Emergency Plan, Maintenance Inspection and Testing, Employee and Contractor Training, Compliance Audits, Incident Investigation, Affected Area survey. Notification procedures, cooperative planning with first responder agencies, local emergency planning committees, as well as Kern County Environmental Health Services Department and EPA submissions. Our company adheres to these systems, programs and procedures in order to comply with Federal, State and local laws, codes and requirements. Delta Liquid Energy strives to operate our facilities with safety as our first priority. The safety of our employees, emergency responders, our neighbors and the general public are instrumental to the well being of our company and the communities we work in. We operate a storage facility for the distribution of propane. We receive rail cars and truck transports into our facility and transport product out of our facility in truck transports and bobtail type delivery vehicles. Delta Liquid Energy trains operators and drivers in the proper start up, operating and emergency procedures. We conduct regular visual inspections, equipment testing and maintenance. We audit our systems and procedures to assure safety and compliance. We work in a proactive relationship with concerned agencies in order to provide safety, training and maintenance records as well as on site invitations for agency training or review.

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
The accidental release prevention and emergency response policies at Delta Liquid Energy: This facility complies with NFPA-58 requirements for LP-Gas storage, and it is our policy to adhere to all applicable federal, state, and local laws.  If an emergency were to occur, it is our policy to notify the Kern County Fire Department and request that they respond to the emergency. We also train employees to handle small emergencies.

A description or our facility and the regulated substances handled:  This facility is a bulk terminal storing LPG for resale to retail propane outlets and end users.  The facility consists of one 30,000-gal., one 24,000gal., one 12,300gal.,one 26,500 and one rail car connected to the process at a time with a water capacity of up to 34,500gal.

The worst-case and alternative release scenarios:  Our worst case scenario is failure of one 34,500-gallon tank car when filled to the greatest amount allowed (88% at 60F), resulting in a vapor cloud explosion.  The resulting distance to the endpoint extends offsite, and public receptors are within the distance to the endpoint.  Our alternative release scenario is a break in a 2-inch diameter pipe, leading to a 10-minute release and explosion.  The resulting distance to the endpoint extends offsite, and public receptors are within the distance to the endpoint.

The general accidental release prevention program and chemical-specific prevention steps:  This facility complies with EPA`s accident prevention rule, the OSHA PSM standard, and all applicable state and local codes and regulations.  The propane system is designed, installed, and maintained in accordance with NFPA-58 and state law.

Five-year accident history ;  We have never had an accident involving propane that caused deaths, injuries, property or environmental damage, evacuations, or shelterings in place.

The emergency response program:  In the event of an emergency involving our propane system, it is our policy to notify the Kern County Fir

e Department and request that they respond to the emergency.  We also continue to train our employees to respond to, and handle small emergencies.  We have made our response plans available to the fire department; members of the fire department have inspected our facility and they have formulated their response plan.

Planned changes to improve safety:  None
